rev.comment: Undid revision 423206961 by [[Special:Contributions/Nadaelko|Nadaelko]] ([[User talk:Nadaelko|talk]]) Please add it to the main article about the timeline, not here
rev.diff:
Line 208: Line 208:
[[File:Tahrir Square on April 1 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 1 April 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square on April 1 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 1 April 2011]]
â
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''':
+
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''': Protests erupted throughout Egypt, with tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Cairo and thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests targeted President Hosni Mubarak's government, and mostly adhered to non-violence. There were some reports of civilian and police casualties.
â
  â
Protesters gather throughout Cairo, in the beginning they were spread throughout the city, however as the day wore on the protesters all started to move towards Tahrir Square.
  â
Protesters arrived to Tahrir in the early afternoon, at this point there were also protesters gathered in Ismalia, Suez and Alexandria (to name a few of the cities). Upon arriving to Tahrir the police started to use force by shooting tear gas in to the crowds and using high-pressure water hoses. Protesters responded and fought to stay in Tahrir. The confrontations went on throughout the night.
+
'''26 January 2011''': '''"Shutting down The Internet"''': After several Facebook groups were created and tweets (from [[Twitter]]) called for mass demonstrations, the Egyptian government shut down internet access for most of the country.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Leaves the Internet |publisher=Renesys.com |date= |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> This was done to cripple one of the protesters' main organizational tools and to impede the flow of news and people.
â
This is the first night that the government tried to block communication; in Tahrir cell phone blocks were set up. Some also report that rubber bullets were used that night.
+
'''28 January 2011''': The '''"Friday of Anger"''' protests began. Hundreds of thousands demonstrated in Cairo and other Egyptian cities after Friday prayers. Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei arrived in Cairo. There were reports of looting. Prisons were opened and burned down, allegedly on orders from then-Minister of the Interior Habib El Adly. Prison inmates to escaped en masse, in what was believed to be an attempt to terrorise protesters. Police forces were withdrawn from the streets, and the military was deployed. International fears of violence grew, but no major casualties were reported. President Hosni Mubarak made his first address to the nation and pledged to form a new government. Later that night clashes broke out in Tahrir Square between revolutionaries and pro-Mubarak demonstrators, leading to the injury of several and the death of some.
â
Late at night the government starts to block Twitter, proxies are used to get around this.
+
'''29 January 2011''': The military presence in Cairo increased. A curfew was declared, but was widely ignored as the flow of defiant protesters to Tahrir Square continued throughout the night. The military reportedly refused to follow orders to fire live ammunition, and exercised restraint overall. There were no reports of major casualties.
  +
'''1 February 2011''': Mubarak made another televised address and offered several concessions. He pledged to not run for another term in the elections planned for September, and pledged political reforms. He stated he would stay in office to oversee a peaceful transition. Small but violent clashes began that night between pro-Mubarak and anti-Mubarak groups.
â
'''26 January 2011''': '''Internet Blackout''':
+
'''2 February 2011''': '''"Battle of the Camel"'''. Violence escalated as waves of Mubarak supporters met anti-government protesters. Some Mubarak supporters on camels and horseback entered Tahrir Square, and tens of casualties were reported. The military tried to limit the violence, repeatedly separating anti-Mubarak and pro-Mubarak groups. President Mubarak reiterated his refusal to step down in interviews with several news agencies. Incidents of violence toward journalists and reporters escalated amid speculation that the violence was being encouraged by Mubarak as a way to bring the protests to an end.
â
After several Facebook groups were created and tweets (from [[Twitter]]) called for mass demonstrations, the Egyptian government shut down internet access for most of the country.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/01/egypt-leaves-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Leaves the Internet |publisher=Renesys.com |date= |accessdate=21 March 2011}}</ref> This was done to cripple one of the protesters' main organizational tools and to impede the flow of news and people.
+
'''6 February 2011''': [[Copts | Egyptian Christians]] held Sunday Mass in Tahrir Square, protected by a ring of Muslims. Negotiations involving Egyptian Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and representatives of the opposition commenced amid continuing protests throughout the nation. The Egyptian army assumed greater security responsibilities, maintaining order and guarding The [[Egyptian Museum | Egyptian Museum of Antiquity]]. Suleiman offered reforms, while others of Mubarak's regime accused foreign nations, including the US, of interfering in Egyptâs affairs.
â
"Anonymous" threatens to start hacking in to government and corporation websites if the internet is shut down in Egypt. Meanwhile Facebook is blocked.
+
'''10 February 2011''': Mubarak formally addressed Egypt amid speculation of a military coup, but rather than resigning (as was widely expected), he simply stated he would delegate some of his powers to Vice President Suleiman, while continuing as Egypt's head of state. Reactions to Mubarak's statement were marked by anger, frustration and disappointment, and throughout various cities there was an escalation of the number and intensity of demonstrations.
â   â
Robert Gibbs makes the first US statement, saying that the Egyptian government should respect the âuniversal rightsâ of Egyptians
  â   â   â
'''27 January 2011''': '''Suez War Zone''':
  â   â
The previous two days had been incredibly bloody and live ammunition was being used in the Suez. News from the Suez was slow in getting out to the rest of the country and the world. Yet much of it was dismissed to be rumors in the beginning.
  â   â
Government endorsed thugs come out in full force. Downtown Cairo echoes with shots and the sound of tear gas being shot at protesters.
  â   â   â
'''28 January 2011''': The '''"Friday of Anger"''':
  â   â
Hundreds of thousands demonstrated in Cairo and other Egyptian cities after Friday prayers. Opposition leader Mohamed ElBaradei arrived in Cairo. There were reports of looting. Prisons were opened and burned down, allegedly on orders from then-Minister of the Interior Habib El Adly. Prison inmates to escaped en masse, in what was believed to be an attempt to terrorise protesters. Police forces were withdrawn from the streets, and the military was deployed. International fears of violence grew, but no major casualties were reported.
  â   â
President Hosni Mubarak made his first address to the nation and pledged to form a new government. Later that night clashes broke out in Tahrir Square between revolutionaries and pro-Mubarak demonstrators, leading to the injury of several and the death of some.
  â   â
This is the first night a curfew is placed, it was originally a transportation curfew of 6:00 PM to 7:00 AM but was quickly changed to an outright full curfew. This is also the first night that the patrol helicopters make their appearance, circling downtown for hours.
  â   â
The National Democratic Party building is set on fire and some looters attempt to raid the Egyptian museum, however protesters attempt to stop them and succeeded to a great extent.
  â   â   â
'''29 January 2011''': '''Cabinet Reforms'''
  â   â
The military presence in Cairo increased. The military reportedly refused to follow orders to fire live ammunition, and exercised restraint overall. There were no reports of major casualties.
  â   â
Downtown looks like a complete war zone as several cars are blown up, roads are torn apart, and ATM's are ransacked.
  â   â
Mubarak refuses to step down but announces that he has changed some cabinet members. Vice President Omar Suleiman, former Intelligence Chief is appointed the long vacant position.
  â   â
Vigilante, neighborhood watches take to the streets in full force to protect their homes from looters in the absence of the police.
  â   â
European nations issue their first statement stating how "worried" they are for the Egyptians but none call for Mubarak to step down.
  â   â   â
'''30 January 2011''': '''"An Orderly Transition of Power"''':
  â   â
President Barack Hussein Obama calls for an "orderly transition of power" but no mention is made of what America's stance is.
  â   â
Mohamed El Baradei addressed the crowds in Tahrir Square for the first time. The speech is seen as largely ineffective and not well planned.
  â   â
Protesters have visibly camped out in Tahrir and claim they will not leave until President Mubarak does.
  â   â   â
'''31 January 2011''':
  â   â
The Army announces that it is a neutral entity and will not use force against the protesters.
  â   â
Several members of the Egyptian opposition call for a "Million Man March" for the following Tuesday.
  â   â   â
'''1 February 2011''': '''March of a Million''':
  â   â
Mubarak made another televised address and offered several concessions. He pledged to not run for another term in the elections planned for September, and pledged political reforms. He stated he would stay in office to oversee a peaceful transition. The protesters call for Mubarak to step down by 4 February 2011 and are adamant about their presence in Tahrir.
  â   â
Clashes break out between the pro-Mubarak protesters and the Pro-Democracy protesters.
  â   â
Banks are closed for the third day in a row and the economic effect is being realized.
  â   â
Several Americans and other nationals are evacuated from the country.
  â   â   â
'''2 February 2011''': '''"Battle of the Camel"'''
  â   â
Violence escalated as waves of Mubarak supporters met anti-government protesters. Some Mubarak supporters on camels and horseback entered Tahrir Square, and tens of casualties were reported. The military tried to limit the violence, repeatedly separating anti-Mubarak and pro-Mubarak groups.
  â   â
President Mubarak reiterated his refusal to step down in interviews with several news agencies. Incidents of violence toward journalists and reporters escalated amid speculation that the violence was being encouraged by Mubarak as a way to bring the protests to an end.
  â   â
Al Jazeera has been told to leave Egypt, yet they defy the orders and continue broadcasting.
  â   â   â
'''3 February 2011''':
  â   â
Clashes continue between Pro-Mubarak and Pro-Democracy protesters.
  â   â
Fighting Kills 6 and wounds 850 protesters. The total death count by now since 25 January is 150<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0</ref>
  â   â
The western powers start urging Mubarak to take the necessary steps and to step down
  â   â
The Army intervenes after a long period of neutrality and places a buffer zone between the Pro-Mubarak and Pro-Democracy protesters.
  â   â
4,000 people in Suez and 2,000 in Ismailia call for Mubarak's departure<ref>http://af.reuters.com/article/tunisiaNews/idAFLDE71014Z20110203?pageNumber=3&virtualBrandChannel=0</ref>
  â   â
Christian Amanpour interviews President Mubarak.
  â   â
The internet fully resumes.
  â   â
Several activists express a clear divide between two camps. Firstly, there are those who see the concessions made by the President as enough and a need to return to normalcy. Secondly, there are those who see that the most important demands have not been met yet, most importantly, Mubarak stepping down<ref>http://www.sandmonkey.org/</ref>.
  â   â   â
'''4 February 2011''': '''"Day of Departure"''':
  â   â
Army tanks close off Kasr El Nil bridge.
  â   â
Plan of March to Presidentâs Palace.
  â   â
Minister of Trade and Industry, Rachid Rachid, is included on the list of those whose assets are frozen.
  â   â
Reports that US officials are calling for the immediate resignation of President Mubarak.
  â   â   â
'''5 February 2011''': '''Mass Resignations''':
  â   â
Resignations of top NDP figures including Gamal Mubarak and Safwat El Sherif.
  â   â
Egyptian Health ministry reports 11 deaths since 25 January while UN claims 300 dead so far<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112515334871490.html</ref>.
  â   â
In Sinai, a gas pipe explodes. The Egyptian state media states it is due to terrorist groups and the possibility of the involvement of the Muslim Brotherhood.
  â   â   â
'''6 February 2011''': [[Copts | Egyptian Christians]] held Sunday Mass in Tahrir Square, protected by a ring of Muslims.
  â   â
Negotiations involving Egyptian Vice President [[Omar Suleiman]] and representatives of the opposition commenced amid continuing protests throughout the nation. The Egyptian army assumed greater security responsibilities, maintaining order and guarding The [[Egyptian Museum | Egyptian Museum of Antiquity]]. Suleiman offered reforms, while others of Mubarak's regime accused foreign nations, including the US, of interfering in Egyptâs affairs.
  â   â
Members of the Muslim Brotherhood claim that they are willing to participate in dialogues with the government to see "how serious the government is willing to take the demands of the people into consideration"<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112515334871490.html</ref>.
  â   â
Most banks reopen in Egypt.
  â   â   â
'''7 February 2011''':
  â   â
The government states that it will implement a 15% increase in salaries and pensions
  â   â
Wael Ghoneim is released by the Central Security and he appears on Dream TV's "Al Ashera Masa'an".
  â   â   â
'''8 February 2011''': '''"Millions Man March"''':
  â   â
While the tents increase within the square, some protestors move to camp outside the Peopleâs Assembly.
  â   â
Vice President Omar Suleiman warns that protests cannot continue such protests for much longer.
  â   â
Vice President Omar Suleiman states that committees will be formed to look at constitutional and legislative reforms.
  â   â   â
'''9 February 2011''':
  â   â
A significant number of Labor Union representatives and workers are present within Tahrir wearing blue uniforms.
  â   â
Tamer Hosni, famous Egyptian singer is attacked in the square as a result of previous statements he made in support of the regime.
  â   â
State TV states that 32 prisoners are released<ref>http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112515334871490.html</ref>.
  â
  â
Human Rights Watch states that there are 232 deaths in Cairo, 52 in Alexandria, 18 in Suez.
  â   â
Foreign Minister, Ahmed Aboul Gheit states that he is âinfuriatedâ by Obamaâs positions and warns of outside intervention.
  â   â   â
'''10 February 2011''':
  â   â
Mubarak formally addressed Egypt amid speculation of a military coup, but rather than resigning (as was widely expected), he simply stated he would delegate some of his powers to Vice President Suleiman, while continuing as Egypt's head of state. Reactions to Mubarak's statement were marked by anger, frustration and disappointment, and throughout various cities there was an escalation of the number and intensity of demonstrations.
  â   â
A great feeling of disappointment is expressed by eyewitnesses and protesters in Tahrir as a result. Many were in tears.
  â   â
Gaber Asfour, newly appointed Culture Minister resigns after a week of taking the position
  â   â
News is reported of the freezing of the assets of three former ministers including the prohibition of their travel.
  â
  â   â
'''11 February 2011''': The '''"Day of Departure"''':
  â   â
Massive protests continued in many cities as Egyptians refused the concessions announced by Mubarak. Finally, at 6:00 PM local time, Suleiman announced Mubarak's resignation, entrusting the Supreme Council of Egyptian Armed Forces with the leadership of the country. Television images show the helicopter of Mubarak going to Sharm El Sheikh.
  â   â   â
'''12 February 2011''':
  â   â
More ministers have their assets frozen such as Former Prime Minister, Ahmed Nazif.
  â   â
In a gesture to a new beginning, protesters cleaned up and renovated Tahrir Square, the epicenter of the demonstrations, although many pledged they would continue protests until all the demands had been met.
    +
'''11 February 2011''': The '''"Friday of Departure"''': Massive protests continued in many cities as Egyptians refused the concessions announced by Mubarak. Finally, at 6:00 pm local time, Suleiman announced Mubarak's resignation, entrusting the Supreme Council of Egyptian Armed Forces with the leadership of the country.
'''13 February 2011''': The Supreme Council dissolved Egyptâs parliament and suspended the Constitution in response to demands by demonstrators. The council declared that it would hold power for six months, or until elections could be held. Calls were made for the the council to provide more details and specific timetables and deadlines. Major protests subsided but did not end. In a gesture to a new beginning, protesters cleaned up and renovated Tahrir Square, the epicenter of the demonstrations, although many pledged they would continue protests until all the demands had been met.
'''13 February 2011''': The Supreme Council dissolved Egyptâs parliament and suspended the Constitution in response to demands by demonstrators. The council declared that it would hold power for six months, or until elections could be held. Calls were made for the the council to provide more details and specific timetables and deadlines. Major protests subsided but did not end. In a gesture to a new beginning, protesters cleaned up and renovated Tahrir Square, the epicenter of the demonstrations, although many pledged they would continue protests until all the demands had been met.
â   â
Clean up continues in areas around Cairo.
  â   â
2,000 Policemen start to protest outside the Ministry of Interior.
  â  
'''17 February 2011''': The army stated it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], and steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News - Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
'''17 February 2011''': The army stated it would not field a candidate in the upcoming presidential elections.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypt-army-says-wont-field-presidential-candidate-2011-02-17T144839Z |title=Egypt army says won't field presidential candidate |publisher=Forexyard.com |date= |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref> Four important figures of the former regime were detained on that day: former interior minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former minister of housing [[Ahmed Maghrabi]] former tourism minister [[Zuheir Garana]], and steel tycoon [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12500968 |title=BBC News - Egypt after Mubarak: Three ex-ministers arrested |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=15 February 2011 |accessdate=20 February 2011}}</ref>
â  
'''2 March 2011''': The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8 |title=Egypt sets constitutional referendum date |publisher=Financial Times |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
'''2 March 2011''': The [[Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2011|constitutional referendum]] was tentatively scheduled for 19 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/d67e07da-4420-11e0-931d-00144feab49a.html#axzz1FTmeSur8 |title=Egypt sets constitutional referendum date |publisher=Financial Times |date=1 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
â  
'''3 March 2011''': A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as Prime Minister and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |title=Egypt's prime minsiter quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Forexyard.com |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
'''3 March 2011''': A day before large protests against him were planned, [[Ahmed Shafik]] stepped down as Prime Minister and was replaced by [[Essam Sharaf]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forexyard.com/en/news/Egypts-prime-minsiter-quits-new-govt-soon-army-2011-03-03T093300Z |title=Egypt's prime minsiter quits, new govt soon-army |publisher=Forexyard.com |date=3 March 2011 |accessdate=16 March 2011}}</ref>
â  
'''5 March 2011''': Several [[State Security Intelligence]] (SSI) buildings were raided across Egypt by protesters, including the headquarters for [[Alexandria Governorate]] and the main national headquarters in [[Nasr City]], Cairo. Protesters stated they raided the buildings to secure documents they believed to show various crimes committed by the SSI against the people of Egypt during Mubarak's rule.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134228359128.html | title=Egypt security building stormed | publisher=Al Jazeera English | date=5 March 2011 | accessdate=7 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12674714 | title=Egyptians demand secret police give up torture secrets | author=Leithead, Alastair | publisher=BBC [[BBC News|News]] | date=8 March 2011 | accessdate=8 March 2011 }}</ref>
'''5 March 2011''': Several [[State Security Intelligence]] (SSI) buildings were raided across Egypt by protesters, including the headquarters for [[Alexandria Governorate]] and the main national headquarters in [[Nasr City]], Cairo. Protesters stated they raided the buildings to secure documents they believed to show various crimes committed by the SSI against the people of Egypt during Mubarak's rule.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134228359128.html | title=Egypt security building stormed | publisher=Al Jazeera English | date=5 March 2011 | accessdate=7 March 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12674714 | title=Egyptians demand secret police give up torture secrets | author=Leithead, Alastair | publisher=BBC [[BBC News|News]] | date=8 March 2011 | accessdate=8 March 2011 }}</ref>
â  
'''6 March 2011''': From the Nasr City headquarters, protesters acquired evidence of mass surveillance and vote rigging, and noted rooms full of videotapes, piles of shredded and burned documents, and cells where activists recounted their experiences of detention and torture.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title = A first step towards prosecutions? | first = Gregg | last = Carlstrom | date = 6 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Jazeera }}</ref>
'''6 March 2011''': From the Nasr City headquarters, protesters acquired evidence of mass surveillance and vote rigging, and noted rooms full of videotapes, piles of shredded and burned documents, and cells where activists recounted their experiences of detention and torture.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/03/2011368410372200.html | title = A first step towards prosecutions? | first = Gregg | last = Carlstrom | date = 6 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Jazeera }}</ref>
â  
'''19 March 2011''': The constitutional referendum was held and passed by 77.27%.<ref name=results>{{cite web |url= http://referendum.eg/84-slideshow/158-2011-03-20-19-09-58.html |title= Ø§ÙØ£Ø±ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¹ÙÙØ© ÙÙØªØµÙÙØª |publisher = Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ© Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¦ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙØ¥Ø´Ø±Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§Ø³ØªÙØªØ§Ø¡ ØªØ¹Ø¯ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù |language=[[Arabic]] |accessdate = 20 March 2011}}</ref>
'''19 March 2011''': The constitutional referendum was held and passed by 77.27%.<ref name=results>{{cite web |url= http://referendum.eg/84-slideshow/158-2011-03-20-19-09-58.html |title= Ø§ÙØ£Ø±ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¹ÙÙØ© ÙÙØªØµÙÙØª |publisher = Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ© Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¦ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙØ¥Ø´Ø±Ø§Ù Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§Ø³ØªÙØªØ§Ø¡ ØªØ¹Ø¯ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù |language=[[Arabic]] |accessdate = 20 March 2011}}</ref>
â  
'''22 March 2011''': Parts of the Interior Ministry building catch fire during police demonstrations outside.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.globaltoronto.com/Fire+sweeps+Egypt+Interior+Ministry+building+police+protest+outside+demand+higher/4484415/story.html | date = 22 Mar 2011 | publisher = Global Tornoto }}</ref>
'''22 March 2011''': Parts of the Interior Ministry building catch fire during police demonstrations outside.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.globaltoronto.com/Fire+sweeps+Egypt+Interior+Ministry+building+police+protest+outside+demand+higher/4484415/story.html | date = 22 Mar 2011 | publisher = Global Tornoto }}</ref>
â  
'''23 March 2011''': The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] orders a law criminalising protests and strikes. Under the new law, anyone organising or calling for a protest will be sentenced to jail and/or a fine of LE500,000 (~100,000 USD).<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 | date = 23 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Masri Al Youm }}</ref>
'''23 March 2011''': The [[Cabinet of Egypt|Egyptian Cabinet]] orders a law criminalising protests and strikes. Under the new law, anyone organising or calling for a protest will be sentenced to jail and/or a fine of LE500,000 (~100,000 USD).<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/371465 | date = 23 Mar 2011 | publisher = Al Masri Al Youm }}</ref>
â  
'''1 April 2011''': The '''"Save the Revolution"''' day: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egyptâs Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref>
'''1 April 2011''': The '''"Save the Revolution"''' day: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators filled Tahrir Square for the largest protest in weeks, demanding that the ruling military council move faster to dismantle lingering aspects of the old regime.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/02/world/middleeast/02egypt.html?_r=1 |title=Protesters Scold Egyptâs Military Council |publisher=Neil MacFarquhar |date=1 April 2011 |accessdate=2 April 2011}}</ref>

'''8 April 2011''': The '''"Friday of Cleansing"''': Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators again filled Tahrir Square, criticizing the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for not following through on revolutionary demands.
